fields.description:
Wireframes available at:

* Dash: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Dashboard+-+refreshed
* Nav: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=39846070
* Filters (for instance landing page): https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Landing+page+filters
* Instance detail page: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Instance+detail+page+-+refreshed
* Launch instance wizard (also use for create launch configuration): https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Launch+instance+wizard+-+refreshed
* Roles landing page: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Roles+Landing+Page
* Role detail page: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Role+details
* delete role: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Delete+Role
* Create role: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Create+Role
fields.summary: Create wireframes for supporting IAM roles

comments.body:
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/807

UX review done and several adjustments already made. Biggest outstanding item is new desktop icon. Creating sub-task for that.
[~dkavanagh] This task should not be in review, wireframes do not exist yet.
I set the same text on the launch config wizard for the role section.

\o/ I slightly updated the wireframe text from what you had in your feature branch. And added a help hover thingie... thanks [~dkavanagh]! We can add the story to make implementation changes based on the UX review and stuff in the next sprint (or this sprint if you get done/bored) :)
I've reviewed the wireframes and the only thing left is the instances filter, which I'm working on right now. (so, yes, this sprint!) There is code review feedback that I'll also add to this PR.
[~dkavanagh] awesome! I'm still working on the wireframes. Still to come: role detail page, create role, delete role...may not get to those today.

a couple of comments where we might want to make tradeoffs.
On the role detail page, we don't deal with trust relationships like AWS. I think that's only for federated creds.
Also on that page, you show a list of instances. That's not a cheap operation due to the levels of indirection. First, I need to pull all the instance profiles to see which ones are for this role, then I'd need to pull the instances and filter by instance profile arns. I'll try this to see how much delay it imposes on the screen loading.
The other thing is for the instances landing page. It is expensive to get the actual list of roles for the instances being shown. I need to look grab the instance list (it would be separately because of how the code is structured), then pull out the instance profile ids, then look get the list of instance profiles and pull out the ones that match the ids we gathered (because iam calls don't support filters). In this case, can we simply show all of the roles in the filter list? If no instances match, the user will see an empty list.

[~dkavanagh], yes we do still do trust relationships, according to [~sjones], IIRC. We do the EC2 service and cross-account access (not the others that AWS does). 

When we discussed this the other day, you thought you might be able to show the list of instances using the role on the role detail page. Certainly if that can't be done in a way that doesn't destroy our performance we can remove that. Let me know how it goes. 

Same for filtering by role (should that be called instance profile instead?). If that is too expensive we can skip it as well. Let me know how that goes as well. 

Let's see how this all falls out when you implement...we can always update the wireframe to remove things that won't work for us. 

Thanks!

I think all the trust relationship stuff would be in the policy since there is no other way to specify the type of role. I'll create 2 types of roles on AWS and see how the policies differ.

I display the instance links on the role detail page now.. not bad, but there's a linked issue that will help with performance even more. (see GUI-1119 branch)

[~dkavanagh] Trust relationships are a separate policy from the access policy. Each role has two policies, one that defines trust relationships and one that defines access, AFAIK from looking at what AWS does. The trust relationship policy is much simpler and for MVP we could leave that as text-only rather than building a policy gen tool to add conditions and such, for now. If customers ask for it, we can add that later.  

You have to include the trust relationship policy (I believe in the API that is the role-policy?) when you create the role...I think you can add the access policy after, like we do for IAM users and groups.
Right, it's just another policy and we could add that at any time, or a trust statement could be added to an existing policy, AFAIK
It's definitely clearer for users to keep them separate, IMHO.

I found out we cannot update the role path, so I've updated the role view to remove the save/cancel buttons and make path non-editable.

I also find http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/APIReference/API_UpdateAssumeRolePolicy.html which makes me think this is the reason the policy is different. It looks like the API call to set the "trust relationship" policy is different. That does complicate things a little, but we could also take the wait and see approach before adding this.

Thanks, [~dkavanagh]...I updated the role detail wireframe to make the path non-editable, removed save changes and cancel buttons, and updated the add access policy button text to clearly differentiate that from the trust policy. 

Let's discuss the trust policy API stuff when we talk today. Thanks!

Another comment on the x-acct access. We should generate that trust policy as specified in the wireframe. You suggest taking the user directly to the policy generator for regular roles, but we also need this for x-acct role since those roles also need a permissions policy.

Hi [~dkavanagh], I think you might be confused by something?  I did not suggest only taking the user to the access policy generator for regular roles, they should be taken to that after the create the role regardless of the type of trust relationship that is created (service or cross-account). Either way, they will need an access policy. Each role needs two policies: The trust policy (which we create based on the role type selected in the create role screen) and the access policy (generated by the add policy generator after they exit the create role screen). 

Please ping me in IRC if that doesn't seem clear to you.
